discussion.content: I believe the answer is single sign on.

I don't know why they are playing a language game. This is supposed to be an IT exam, not a language exam.

The user already authenticated, now he/she wants to open a new app and was not prompted for authentication. This is an example of single sign-on
Ans Single Sign-on

comments.content:
CompTIA has learned well from Cisco.
:(

discussion.content:
In my understanding Permission inheritance is for the folder and sub-folders and SSO for the OS, systems, programs and applications.
My answer is Single sign on.

Permission inheritance doesn't really fit the question.
Single-sign on deals with not requiring multiple authentications across systems/applications, as the question asks/presents

questions.question_text: A company requires multifactor authentication. When accessing one of the available RemoteApp programs that requires authentication, the user is not prompted to enter a pin. Which of the following BEST describes this scenario?

discussion.content: A, B, and C are all “something you know”, which is also what’s already in the question. Thumbprint is the only one that’s different, making it multifactor.

comments.content:
For reasons lost to time, tempered by the philosophical ideology of just because, a PIN is actually considered different than a username/password combo.
It's stupid, but it's accepted as factual in the industry. Press the believe button.

Never mind... the industry has evolved.
https://www.onespan.com/topics/multi-factor-authentication
The PIN is only considered separate if it is a ONE TIME PIN.
But then that would make both the PIN and the Thumbprint correct answers.
CompTIA spits out unscored questions. Because reasons.

discussion.content: in my opinion, it's because he trying to set a multifactor for workstation and nowadays is more accurate to set pin code using SMS rather having a thumb key usb or equivalent

Selected Answer: D
Something you are

comments.content: My best guess here is fingerprints are widely used for device multifactor auth and not network multifactor. Biometrics still need to be adopted more as a option and the more common method for network login remains one time PINs.

discussion.content: This better be a question that is not marked. Thumb print is something you are. Password and Username is something you know. PIN if it is one time use is multi factor but that still makes both finder print and PIN the answer. Such a stupid question.

https://www.onespan.com/topics/multi-factor-authentication
Ugh. Definitions evolve as the industry evolves. A ONE-TIME PIN plus 'crap you know' is a multifactor. But that would make thumb print just as legitimate...
Good luck on the test.
C is correct

comments.content: One of my jobs required us to use our Fingerprint after logging in with our username and password, by having a Fingerprint dongle attached to the laptop

In the very least the answer PIN could be worded better, PIN is defined as something you know because its a Personal Identification Number. What you're referring to is a Software Token on an Authenticator.

discussion.content:
I use this at work. A PIN is set up on an authenticator app in your phone or your email. this is like "what you have", if you left your phone at home you cannot log in. 
C may be correct.
Thumbprint may be seen as complex for a technician to set up for login realistically.
A pin is something you have if it’s sent to you from the server By text or email? Unlike a password you pick
someone explain to me why it isn't a thumbprint -_-

comments.content: here a technician is working. If technician use his/her thumbprint, how other users could access? need to think on it.
That makes no sense! Please elaborate.

It is thumbprint. All the others qualify as something you know which is also the authentication method currently used. For it to be multifactor it must be different. In this case Thumbprint, something you are.

questions.question_text:
A technician is implementing multifactor authentication for logins to the network. The network already requires a username and password to authenticate users.
Which of the following should the technician add to meet the multifactor requirement?

choices.D: Map the printer by hostname rather than IP address.
choices.C: Configure the printer to use a dynamic IP address.
choices.B: Locally attach the printer to the user's device.
choices.A: Configure the printer NIC to use full duplexing.

discussion.content: It's a typo. Should be static. Came out in the exam. Static was in it.
I suspect the option in the exam may be to assign a static IP address to the printer.

comments.content:
Definitely Static, I think. 
The scenario is after DHCP failure and restarted the printer probably picks another IP.
Probably whoever wrote this out and copied it wrong
That sounds most likely tbf, just a typo.

discussion.content: This i got from my exam and its says dynamic not static so what i choose is the D.

It is a typo error in the answer, it should be the static IP address. You cannot configure network printer with dynamic If you do that, each time the DCHP renews IPs, the users are going to get disconnected because the printer may likely be assigned a different IP.

The answer is clearly dynamic address because this creates both job security, and a steady stream of white male tears. And as someone who's played through the entire FFXIV storyline, I can confirm than our tears are ambrosia.
...
It's a typo. The tech screwed up and failed to make a DHCP reservation/configure a static IP. And now you have to map ALL of the computers all over again. Sucks to suck.

In my experience, printers are always wanting to keep a static IP address -- usually would let DHCP assign the IP then reserve it so it doesn't change, so I will definitely say that C is wrong.

D is the only other option I can see as being correct.

B is just silly as it's for multiple users -- on a technical level you MIGHT be able to plug the printer into more than one PC, but that's just a silly solution if even possible.
Correct anwser is D

Which of the following should the technician do to ensure all users can print?

questions.question_text: A user downloaded a program from a website. After saving the file, the user cannot find the executable. Which of the following is MOST likely the cause?

choices.A: The file was quarantined by an anti-malware software.
choices.D: File permissions do not allow the user to access the file.
choices.C: The file is incompatible with the operating system.
choices.B: The host-based firewall blocked the download.
Restart the computer in safe mode.
choices.D: Search for software related to the pop-ups.
choices.A: Kill all processes that are not related to Windows.
choices.E: Uninstall the network driver from the Device Manager.

comments.content: *Correction* Therefore as 'disconnecting the network cable' is not an option....

No. In CompTIA World, you would only uninstall the network driver if reinstalling it would fix an issue. Killing processes might not do anything if they auto-restart, which many legit processes do no matter how many times you murder them to death in Task Manager. D is just a red herring tied to a rabbit on methamphetamines running after a wild goose. F is essentially done by way of running the device in safe mode.
This is why dump sites are so popular with these certs. A lot of exam questions are disgustingly horrendous where it's not find the best answers, but rather, find the least ****ty answers.
Good luck on the test.

discussion.content: If malware is suspected would you not quarantine the computer as soon as possible. Therefore as 'disconnecting the network cable' being an option would E. Uninstall the network driver from the Device Manager. not be a viable option?

A user reports unwanted pop-ups are appearing on a computer's screen, and the system is performing slowly. Which of the following should a technician do
